content.text:
# Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Miniseries or Television Movie__disambig_1

}}
The Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Television Movie or Limited Series is an award given by the Screen Actors Guild to honor the finest acting achievements in Miniseries or Television Movie.
In this category four actors have received two awards each: Helen Mirren (Elizabeth I, Phil Spector), Queen Latifah (Life Support, Bessie), Kate Winslet (Mildred Pierce, Mare of Easttown), and Alfre Woodard (The Piano Lesson, ''Miss Evers' Boys)
The actress with the most nominations in this category is Helen Mirren with five for her roles in The Passion of Ayn Rand, Door to Door, The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone, Elizabeth I, and Phil Spector).
Winners and nominees
won twice in this category for The Piano Lesson (1995) and Miss Evers' Boys (1997)]]
won for The Late Shift (1996)]]
won for Gia (1998)]]
won for Introducing Dorothy Dandridge (1999)]]
won for If These Walls Could Talk 2 (2000)]]
won for Life with Judy Garland: Me and My Shadows (2001)]]
won Angels in America (2003)]]
won for The Lion in Winters (2003)]]
won twice for Elizabeth I (2005) and Phil Spector (2013)]]
won for John Adams (2008)]]
won for twice for Mildred Pierce (2011) and Mare of Easttown (2021)]]
won for Game Change (2012)]]
for The People v. O. J. Simpson: American Crime Story (2016)]]
won Big Little Lies (2017)]]
won for Fosse/Verdon (2019)]]
won for The Queen's Gambit (2020)]]
won for George & Tammy (2022)]]
